holidays.name: Apple Cider Day
holidays.description: A celebration dedicated to the delicious and refreshing drink made from pressed apples. Perfect for cozy fall sipping!
holidays.origin: Apple cider has been a popular autumn beverage for centuries in North America and Europe, and this day celebrates its seasonal charm.
holidays.funFact: Cider apples are different from eating apples ‚Äî they're specially grown to produce a perfectly balanced cider.

holidays.name: Anniversary of the Mona Lisa‚Äôs Theft (1911)
holidays.description: Commemorates the infamous day the Mona Lisa was stolen from the Louvre by Vincenzo Peruggia, sparking global intrigue.
holidays.origin: In 1911, the Italian handyman Peruggia stole the painting believing it should be returned to Italy, and it was recovered two years later.
holidays.funFact: The theft actually boosted the Mona Lisa's popularity, turning it into a worldwide icon.

holidays.name: Use Your Common Sense Day
holidays.description: A quirky reminder to apply logic and practical thinking in everyday situations instead of rushing into decisions blindly.
holidays.origin: An informal observance encouraging everyone to pause and think critically before acting.
holidays.funFact: This day humorously reminds us that common sense isn't so common after all!

holidays.name: Jukebox Day
holidays.description: Celebrates the musical charm and nostalgia of the classic jukebox, which pumped out tunes in diners and bars.
holidays.origin: The jukebox was at its peak mid-20th century; this day honors its influence on social music culture.
holidays.funFact: The first jukebox was invented in 1889 and could play multiple records on demand!
